page.title: 02LANDSCAPE
page.content: This mainly{moorland}area is part of the huge{granite}batholith which underlies the South west Peninsula. Granite boulders often protrude through the moors. The{highest point}is 264 metres above sea level on{Caerloggas Downs, where panoramic views of much of mid-Cornwall can be enjoyed. The landscape of the area is dominated by{spoil heaps}of china clay waste and their adjoining{water-filled {pits.}Associated with these, are large {storage tanks}containing refined clay and{huge conveyor}belts which carry waste from pits to spoil heaps. Another prominent feature is the deep-sided valley of the{White River, its water turned milky by china clay. The valley sides are{bracken-covered at Carthew but are{wooded lower down.
